SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 8

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every two months

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On Sunday

4. Were you often invited to other homes or was most visiting done without an invitation? Mostly without invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the afternoon

That about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "make potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "stopped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from homestead to homestead, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting each and every? 8

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every two months

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Usually without invitation

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the afternoon

That about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "would you like to have dinner?" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "stopped by"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in houses? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Gives dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a week, monthly, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. Include the school Christmas tree, picnic, etc., if you have not answered these in the School Questionnaire.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?
Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?
Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?
To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?
How were babies and small children provided for?
How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?
Has there card playing for a prize?
What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, book sales, and other activities. If there were no school clubs, tell what clubs or organizations met there.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it—individuals, the municipality, organization, etc.? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?
